scenarioDescription:
The K2-36 Exoplanetary System


Overview

K2-36 is a star with 0.79 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.72 times its radius. It is located 357.95 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 1.4 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

K2-36 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the K2-36 system


K2-36 b

K2-36 b was discovered by the K2 observatory, in 2016-08, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.02 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-36 b is 3.902 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-36 b is 1.430 that of Earth. At 3.902 Earth masses, K2-36 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


K2-36 c

K2-36 c was discovered by the K2 observatory, in 2016-08, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-36 c is 7.804 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-36 c is 3.200 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, K2-36 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-36, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the K2.
name: K2-36 - System With 2 Exolanets
